claims.text: Over five days, four million Texans lost power during the coldest winter storm in fifty years.
ERCOT reported that Texas was four minutes away from total grid collapse during the storm.
claims.context: ERCOT's report during February 2021 winter storm.

claims.text: Hundreds died during the February 2021 storm, including an 11-year-old boy who froze to death.
The temperature in Texas dropped below zero during the week of Valentine's Day 2021.
From 2010 to 2020, Texas's population increased by 4 million people and the economy grew by 35%.
claims.context: Population and economic growth in Texas.

claim_reports.claim_text: Over five days, four million Texans lost power during the coldest winter storm in fifty years.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that over four million Texans lost power during the coldest winter storm in fifty years, specifically Winter Storm Uri in February 2021, as confirmed by multiple high-reliability sources including a final report and the Texas Comptroller.

supports.title: 2021 Texas Power Grid Failure – a preventable disaster - DEITABASE
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that during Winter Storm Uri from February 14-20, 2021, approximately 69% of Texans experienced power outages, with many enduring these disruptions for an average of 42 hours. This supports the claim that millions of Texans lost power during the storm, although the specific figure of four million is not directly confirmed in the text.
supports.snippet: In 2021, Winter Storm Uri brought record-breaking low temperatures to the people of Texas, overwhelming the under-designed Texas power grid.

supports.title: Final Report on February 2021 Freeze Underscores Winterization ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that over four million Texans lost power during the February 2021 winter storm, with significant disruptions lasting several days.
supports.snippet: More than 4.5 million people in Texas lost power – some for as long as four days. Tragically, the loss of electricity caused the deaths of ...

supports.title: Winter Storm Uri 2021 - Texas Comptroller
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that during Winter Storm Uri, over 69% of Texans experienced power outages, with many outages lasting several days, which aligns with the claim that four million Texans lost power during the storm.
supports.snippet: The UT-Austin report found that Uri, although not the most severe Texas winter storm on record, caused the most loss of electricity.

claim_reports.claim_text: ERCOT reported that Texas was four minutes away from total grid collapse during the storm.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that ERCOT reported Texas was four minutes and 37 seconds away from total grid collapse during the February 2021 storm, directly supporting the claim.

supports.title: ERCOT Blackout 2021 - UT Energy Institute
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the extreme winter storm in February 2021 that led to significant electricity generation failures in Texas, indicating that ERCOT reported being very close to a total grid collapse during this event.
supports.snippet: In February 2021, an extreme winter storm event caused a massive electricity generation failure in the state of Texas, which resulted in a loss of power for ...

supports.title: Final Report on February 2021 Freeze Underscores Winterization ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that ERCOT was indeed close to a total grid collapse during the storm, as they ordered rolling blackouts to manage the situation.
supports.snippet: The Texas grid operator (Electric Reliability Council of Texas or ERCOT) ordered a total of 20,000 MW of rolling blackouts in an effort to ...

supports.title: Impact of Winter Storm Uri on Texas' Petrochemical Industry
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ERCOT reported the Texas power grid was four minutes and 37 seconds away from complete failure during the storm, indicating a critical situation that could have led to total grid collapse.
supports.snippet: Texas' independent electric grid managed by ERCOT was four and a half minutes away from complete collapse, which could have crippled the state ...

supports.title: Cascading risks: Understanding the 2021 winter blackout in Texas
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ERCOT reported the Texas power grid was four minutes and 37 seconds away from complete failure during the storm, which aligns with the claim about being four minutes away from total grid collapse.
supports.snippet: On the morning of February 15, the Texas grid's frequency declined to below 59.4 Hz for four minutes and 23 seconds. Had it remained there for a full 9 min, ...

supports.title: Texas was minutes away from monthslong power outages, officials say
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ERCOT reported the Texas power grid was four minutes and 37 seconds away from complete failure during the storm, indicating a critical situation that could have led to catastrophic consequences.
supports.snippet: Texas' power grid was “seconds and minutes” away from a catastrophic failure that could have left Texans in the dark for months.

mixed.title: 2021 Texas Power Grid Failure – a preventable disaster - DEITABASE
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that during the storm, a significant portion of the Texas power grid's capacity was lost, which aligns with the claim that ERCOT reported a critical situation, although it does not explicitly mention being four minutes away from total collapse.
mixed.snippet: Over the course of just four hours on February 15th, 40% of the grid's capacity went offline, forcing the Electric Reliability Council of Texas ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Hundreds died during the February 2021 storm, including an 11-year-old boy who froze to death.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that hundreds died during the February 2021 storm, including an 11-year-old boy. Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that Cristian Pavon died due to carbon monoxide poisoning and hypothermia during the storm, highlighting the severe impact of the weather conditions.

supports.title: Autopsy: 11-year-old Conroe boy died of carbon monoxide poisoning
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the tragic death of 11-year-old Cristian Pavon during the February 2021 storm, attributing his death to carbon monoxide poisoning, which occurred during a power outage amid extreme cold. This supports the claim that hundreds died during the storm, including an 11-year-old boy.
supports.snippet: Autopsy results released for 11-year-old who died during the Texas winter freeze. Police say Christian Pavon died of carbon monoxide poisoning.

supports.title: Conroe-area family sues Texas' power grid operator after their son ...
supports.evidence_summary: The article confirms that Cristian Pavon, an 11-year-old boy, died of suspected hypothermia during a severe winter storm in Texas, which aligns with the claim about deaths during the storm.
supports.snippet: Cristian Pineda, 11, died of suspected hypothermia in his family's home last week in Conroe after a severe winter storm dropped temperatures ...

supports.title: Mother of 11-year-old Texas boy who died during power outage ...
supports.evidence_summary: The article confirms that Cristian Pineda, an 11-year-old boy, died during the February 2021 storm, specifically stating he was found unresponsive in his bed after trying to stay warm with his younger brother.
supports.snippet: Cristian Pineda, 11, was found unresponsive in his bed Tuesday after spending the night with his 3-year-old brother in an effort to stay warm, ...

supports.title: Texas Family Sues Power Provider, Utility Overseer After Son Dies ...
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the tragic death of 11-year-old Cristian Pavon, who died from hypothermia during a severe winter storm in Texas, highlighting the negligence of power providers during the extended power outage that left many without heat.
supports.snippet: The family of Cristian Pavon says he died at age 11 because of negligence. The family lives in Conroe, a city about 45 miles north of central ...

claim_reports.claim_text: The temperature in Texas dropped below zero during the week of Valentine's Day 2021.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that temperatures in Texas dropped below zero during the week of Valentine's Day 2021, with specific records such as -2 degrees Fahrenheit in Dallas/Fort Worth on February 16, 2021, and consecutive days of below-freezing temperatures in Austin.

supports.title: February 2021: Historic Winter Storm and Arctic Outbreak
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the temperature in Texas dropped below zero during the week of Valentine's Day 2021, specifically noting a record low of -2 degrees Fahrenheit in Dallas/Fort Worth on February 16, 2021.
supports.snippet: Records for Dallas/Fort Worth and Waco: The lowest low/minimum temperature was: DFW: -2 deg F on February 16th, 2021 (All-time record low for ...

supports.title: Year in Review - Winter Storm Uri | Open Data | City of Austin, Texas
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that during February 2021, Austin experienced consecutive days of below-freezing temperatures, which supports the claim that temperatures dropped below zero in Texas during that time.
supports.snippet: In February 2021 ... Austin received more than six inches of snow, nearly an inch of ice from freezing rain, and consecutive days of below-freezing temperatures.

supports.title: LOOK BACK: It's been 2 years since Texas' devastating winter storm ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that during Winter Storm Uri, which began on February 14, 2021, Austin experienced consecutive days of below-freezing temperatures, indicating that temperatures dropped below zero in Texas during that week.
supports.snippet: 107.5 hours at or below 33 degrees: Starting on Feb. 12 and continuing through early Feb. 17, San Antonio saw below-freezing temperatures.

unclear.title: The Great Texas Freeze: February 11-20, 2021 | News
unclear.evidence_summary: On February 11-20, 2021, a historical winter event occurred that set many records, including being the first billion-dollar weather disaster of that year.
unclear.snippet: On February 11-20, 2021, a historical winter event occurred that set many records, including being the first billion-dollar weather disaster of that year.

claim_reports.claim_text: From 2010 to 2020, Texas's population increased by 4 million people and the economy grew by 35%.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that Texas's population increased by approximately 4 million people (15.9% growth) from 2010 to 2020, and that the economy grew by about 35%, as indicated by multiple high-reliability sources confirming both population and GDP growth.

supports.title: Texas Statewide Overview
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that Texas's population grew by 15.9% from 2010 to 2020, which translates to an increase of over 4 million people, and the state's GDP rose by an average annual rate of 3.6%, which aligns with the claim of economic growth of 35%.
supports.snippet: In 2020, Texas had a gross domestic product (GDP) of $1.8 trillion, about 8.5 percent of the U.S. GDP. Between 2010 and 2020, Texas GDP rose by an average ...

supports.title: 2020 Census results and what it means for redistricting
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that Texas's population increased by approximately 4 million residents from 2010 to 2020, as stated in the claim.
supports.snippet: The population of Texas grew by approximately 4 million residents. The 2020 census puts the state's population at more than 29.1 million people, ...

supports.title: Economy of Texas - Wikipedia
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that Texas's population increased significantly from 2010 to 2020, with a growth rate of 15.9%, and that the state's GDP rose by an average annual rate of 3.6%, which aligns with the claim of a 35% economic growth over the same period.
supports.snippet: The economy of the State of Texas is the second largest by GDP in the United States after that of California. It has a gross state product of $2.769 trillion as ...

supports.title: State output remains distinctly Texan, while jobs mix increasingly ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that Texas's population grew by 15.9% from 2010 to 2020, which translates to an increase of over 4 million people, and the state's GDP rose by an average annual rate of 3.6%, suggesting significant economic growth during that period.
supports.snippet: Texas' employment composition has increasingly come to resemble the entirety of the US, more so than even California or New York.

mixed.title: 2020 picture of Texas comes into focus: A diverse state dominated ...
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that Texas's population increased by about 4 million residents from 2010 to 2020, supporting the first part of the claim. However, there is no mention of the economy's growth rate during this period, leaving that aspect of the claim unaddressed.
mixed.snippet: Texas added about 4 million new residents from 2010 to 2020, making it the third fastest-growing state. At the same time, it also became more diverse.

mixed.title: TEXAS: 2020 Census
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that Texas's population increased by 15.9% from 2010 to 2020, which translates to approximately 4 million people, but does not provide information about the economy's growth during that period.
mixed.snippet: The Lone Star State, the nation's second-most populous after California, grew 15.9% to 29145505 from 2010 to 2020.

transcript_data.text: The week of Valentine's Day 2021, the temperature dropped below zero. Nobody could remember it being this cold for this long. This was Texas, not Siberia. But Texas is the energy state. There was nothing to fear. Just go home, turn on the heat, and hunker down. That's how it should have gone. Instead, over five days, four million Texans lost power during what turned out to be the coldest winter storm in a half a century. Hundreds died, including an 11-year-old boy who froze to death in his sleep. The state's electric grid operator, the Electric Reliability Council of Texas, ERCOT, later reported the state was just four minutes away from total grid collapse. The media was quick to blame the state government for not being fully prepared and not acting fast enough. This may be true, but ERCOT's mistakes were symptoms, not the cause, of the problem. The real cause is decades of misguided policies that have left the Lone Star state with an unreliable energy infrastructure. It's a cautionary tale that the rest of the country needs to learn from. From 2010 to 2020, the population of Texas increased by 4 million people, and the state's economy grew by 35%. But while all this growth was happening, the state's reliable energy capacity was actually shrinking. Meanwhile, its unreliable energy capacity was surging. In fact, it almost tripled. Let's break this down. Reliable energy is fossil fuels—coal and natural gas—and nuclear. These fuels produce a near-constant flow of electricity. Unreliable, or variable energy, is renewable energy—wind and solar. They're unreliable because they depend on the whims of Mother Nature. In 2020, Texans got 25% of their energy from renewables. During the February storm, however, that fell to 8%, at one point reaching a deadly low of just 1.5%. The reason? Renewable energy only works when the weather cooperates, but it's useless when it doesn't—like when it conjures up a giant snowstorm. Solar panels don't capture sunlight and wind turbines don't spin when covered in snow and ice. Given renewables' unreliability, how is it that Texas, of all places, became so dependent on them? That story begins in 1999, when Texas politicians on the left and the right fell in love with the idea that they could turn the state into a green energy powerhouse. It sounded like a great idea at the time: Instead of passing any new mandates, they would do it by offering massive subsidies, marketed as "incentives," to produce wind and solar power. This ended up working out great for the wind and solar companies, but not so great for reliable energy providers. To illustrate this, imagine that you own a restaurant. One day you learn that your competitor down the street is getting government support. He gets so much help that, instead of charging his customers, he can pay them to eat his food. Not surprisingly, your customers abandon your restaurant for his. Your competitor prospers off the taxpayers' backs while your business withers. Let's apply this analogy to the real world of renewable energy. Wind and solar get so much in subsidies they're guaranteed a profit. And unlike fossil fuel producers, they're not even required to provide reliable power. It's no wonder fossil fuel plants are closing, and nuclear plants are not being built. The wind and solar companies are protected from the laws of supply and demand. They can't lose, and the fossil fuel plants can't compete. That's how out of whack the Texas electricity market has become. Since 2006, the state has subsidized renewable energy to the tune of $19 billion. All of this came right out of Texans' wallets, courtesy of ever-increasing electric bills and rising property taxes. And what does Texas have to show for it? An electric grid that failed when Texans needed it most. Unfortunately, this scenario is playing out across America. Over the past decade, the federal government has spent over $230 billion on energy subsidies, and that doesn't even include subsidies the states give away. It's true that Uncle Sam also grants favors to fossil fuel companies. Renewable energy advocates love to point this out, but here's what they neglect to mention: compared to fossil fuel companies, for every unit of electricity generated, Washington subsidizes wind 17 times and solar 75 times more. Yet, despite all this aid, renewables provide just 4 percent of the country's total energy supply. The verdict is in: renewable energy is expensive and unreliable. And if it can render America's leading power producer powerless, it can do the same to your state. Government meddling got us into this mess. It's time for politicians to step aside and let the free market get us out of it. I'm Jason Isaac from the Texas Public Policy Foundation, for Prager University.

segments.text:
The week of Valentine's Day 2021, 
the temperature dropped below zero.

Nobody could remember it 
being this cold for this long.
This was Texas, not Siberia.

But Texas is the energy state. There 
was nothing to fear. Just go home,
turn on the heat, and hunker down.
That's how it should have gone.

Instead, over five days, four million 
Texans lost power during what turned

out to be the coldest winter storm 
in a half a century. Hundreds died,

including an 11-year-old boy 
who froze to death in his sleep.

The state's electric grid operator, the 
Electric Reliability Council of Texas,

ERCOT, later reported the state was just 
four minutes away from total grid collapse.
The media was quick to blame the state government

for not being fully prepared 
and not acting fast enough.

This may be true, but ERCOT's mistakes were 
symptoms, not the cause, of the problem.

The real cause is decades of 
misguided policies that have

left the Lone Star state with an 
unreliable energy infrastructure.

It's a cautionary tale that the rest 
of the country needs to learn from.

From 2010 to 2020, the population of 
Texas increased by 4 million people,

and the state's economy grew by 35%. But 
while all this growth was happening,

the state's reliable energy 
capacity was actually shrinking.

Meanwhile, its unreliable energy capacity 
was surging. In fact, it almost tripled.
Let's break this down.

Reliable energy is fossil fuels—coal and 
natural gas—and nuclear. These fuels produce

a near-constant flow of electricity. Unreliable, 
or variable energy, is renewable energy—wind and

solar. They're unreliable because they 
depend on the whims of Mother Nature.

In 2020, Texans got 25% of their energy 
from renewables. During the February storm,

however, that fell to 8%, at one point 
reaching a deadly low of just 1.5%.

The reason? Renewable energy only 
works when the weather cooperates,

but it's useless when it doesn't—like 
when it conjures up a giant snowstorm.

Solar panels don't capture sunlight and wind 
turbines don't spin when covered in snow and ice.

Given renewables' unreliability, how is it that 
Texas, of all places, became so dependent on them?

That story begins in 1999, when Texas politicians 
on the left and the right fell in love with the

idea that they could turn the state into a green 
energy powerhouse. It sounded like a great idea

at the time: Instead of passing any new mandates, 
they would do it by offering massive subsidies,

marketed as "incentives," to produce wind 
and solar power. This ended up working

out great for the wind and solar companies, but 
not so great for reliable energy providers.

To illustrate this, imagine that you own a 
restaurant. One day you learn that your competitor

down the street is getting government support. 
He gets so much help that, instead of charging

his customers, he can pay them to eat his food. 
Not surprisingly, your customers abandon your

restaurant for his. Your competitor prospers off 
the taxpayers' backs while your business withers.

Let's apply this analogy to the 
real world of renewable energy.

Wind and solar get so much in 
subsidies they're guaranteed a profit.

And unlike fossil fuel producers, they're 
not even required to provide reliable power.

It's no wonder fossil fuel plants are closing, 
and nuclear plants are not being built.

The wind and solar companies are protected 
from the laws of supply and demand.
They can't lose, and the fossil fuel plants

can't compete. That's how out of whack 
the Texas electricity market has become.

Since 2006, the state has subsidized 
renewable energy to the tune of $19 billion.

All of this came right out of Texans' wallets, 
courtesy of ever-increasing electric bills

and rising property taxes. And what 
does Texas have to show for it?

An electric grid that failed 
when Texans needed it most.

Unfortunately, this scenario 
is playing out across America.

Over the past decade, the federal government 
has spent over $230 billion on energy subsidies,

and that doesn't even include 
subsidies the states give away.

It's true that Uncle Sam also grants 
favors to fossil fuel companies.

Renewable energy advocates love to point this 
out, but here's what they neglect to mention:

compared to fossil fuel companies, for 
every unit of electricity generated,

Washington subsidizes wind 17 
times and solar 75 times more.

Yet, despite all this aid, renewables provide just 
4 percent of the country's total energy supply.

The verdict is in: renewable energy 
is expensive and unreliable. And if

it can render America's leading power producer 
powerless, it can do the same to your state.

Government meddling got us into this mess. 
It's time for politicians to step aside
and let the free market get us out of it.

I'm Jason Isaac from the Texas Public 
Policy Foundation, for Prager University.
